;政府对香港顶尖运动员的资助增加了 8 亿港元（1.02 亿美元） ）一家体育培训机构的负责人表示，过去十年来，当局旨在帮助他们获得技能，以便在退休后在其他职业上取得成功。

;

;香港体育学院主席邓竞成周日表示，香港精英运动员发展基金已从 2011-12 财政年度的约 2 亿港元创始基金增至 10 亿港元。

;

;“我们致力于建立一个以科学为基础、 “我们在训练精英运动员时采取了以运动员为中心的方法。”唐在广播节目中说道。

;

;该基金目前发放补助金并提供医疗、保险和住宿等支持服务。它还鼓励42个学科领域的顶尖运动员在体育和教育方面的双重职业发展。

;

;香港赛马会和政府还提供了3亿港元资助各种运动医学研究项目，以增加唐表示，当地运动员在国际比赛中的竞争力。

;

;这位前警察局长表示，他自四月份以来执掌的该研究所仍然致力于支持运动员的双重职业发展，提供表现支持以及学术和个人发展计划。

;

;唐说，当局已支持 49 名精英运动员在 2022-23 学年豁免学术要求，获得大学录取，并补充说，该学院一直在与该市的八所公立高等教育机构合作

;

;香港“非常有信心”启德体育公园将在全运会前做好准备

;

;除了学术支持外，邓表示，该研究所还将提供个人发展研讨会，以确保运动员的全面成长。

;

;“训练和学校结束后，运动员所剩的时间不多了。我们不会让他们脱离世界发生的事情，不去培养他们的个人价值观和世界观。”他说。

;

;唐还鼓励家长让他们的孩子尝试精英体育奖学金

;

;“家长可能会担心，成为一名精英运动员意味着 30 岁就退休，没有任何技能。事实并非如此，”他说。

;

;“有政府的支持，以及该研究所与体育联合会和奥林匹克委员会之间的协调，以促进运动员成功过渡到退休。”

;< p>;体育学院自2015年起与沙田林大辉书院和英基学校基金会合作，为学生运动员提供灵活的学习时间表和额外的学术支持。

;

;“我们的同事做了很多工作开展外展工作，让学生和家长了解学院的精英体育训练并不是“因为在学校表现不佳而追求体育”的情况。如今这种定性已不准确。”唐说。

;

;他表示，自此以来，他曾与文化体育及旅游局、香港体育总会、奥林匹克委员会以及各个国家体育协会的官员会面。他于 4 月上任，并补充说，他们的目标是一致的。

;

;青少年体操运动员选择代表香港而不是澳大利亚代表奥运会后，将目光投向了奥运会

;

;全运会将于 2025 年举行”预计明年年底开放。

;

;政府去年 12 月表示，计划在奥运会期间在该市举办 8 项体育赛事，预计将举行足球、橄榄球、击剑和手球项目于启德体育公园。

;一对夫妇将儿子困在出租车里一个小时，然后斥责救起他的路人在大陆社交媒体上引起了愤怒。

;

;车主的父母将钥匙和孩子一起留在了出租车内，他们拒绝打破窗户并将他扔下的呼吁。来自中国西南部四川省的救援人员林姓人士表示，目前已获释。

;

;林某与朋友在街上吃饭时，听到路人谈论被困孩子，他似乎尽管努力吸引他的注意力，但他还是一动不动。

;

;他赶紧过去看看发生了什么事，得知父母担心修理出租车损坏的费用。

;

;担心得知孩子因缺氧可能有生命危险，林某询问是否可以砸碎窗户，但父母没有回答。

;

;据林某称，无论他告诉他们多少次生命比窗户更重要，他会赔偿他们的损失，他们不给许可。

;

;林在社交媒体上发布的一段视频显示，人们在绿色出租车周围敲打车窗，以吸引人们的注意。孩子的注意力。身穿白衣的林用锤子砸碎窗户，将男孩举到安全的地方。另一位路人也上前帮忙。

;

;但林的善举并没有得到孩子家长的赞赏。

;

;一分钟后，林面对孩子的母亲感到震惊： “她说她的孩子很困，但醒来时很害怕，”他告诉星视频。

;

;后来，林妈妈给林打电话，警告他从社交媒体上删除该事件的视频。

;

;林告诉星视频，他对父母的批评​​感到非常沮丧，但他相信自己做了正确的事情：“我很担心。”他说。

;

;网上很多人支持林的行为，这个故事在社交媒体平台抖音上吸引了超过 28,000 条评论。

;

;“孩子的生命还不如一块玻璃？这孩子有这样的父母真是可悲。”一条评论写道，而另一条评论则问道：“母亲怎么能说孩子太困了呢？”

;

;荒谬的育儿方式在中国屡见不鲜。

;

;上个月出现了一个这样的故事，讲述的是一名妇女在得知儿子在同学的生日聚会上吃了一块蛋糕后，强迫儿子喝橄榄油、椰子油和亚麻籽油的混合物来催吐。

;

;4月，中国东部一位霸道父亲试图强迫24岁的女儿与初恋情人分手，研究生毕业后寻找更好的男人，在社交媒体上遭到广泛批评。 .

;2003年，92岁的Fauja Singh准备跑马拉松在纽约，一些旁观者因为他的头巾和胡须而称他为“奥萨马·本·拉登”。尽管身体不适，辛格作为一名锡克教徒，还是在七小时内完成了马拉松，证明了自己的勇气。

;

;辛格在终点线倒下，但在接受急救之前再次站起来，就像他所做的那样不希望媒体上出现锡克教崩溃的照片。他说：“锡克教的自豪感受到威胁。”

;

;辛格的故事在全球锡克教之路上有专题报道，这是一个在线知识库，旨在通过分享奋斗和坚韧的故事来促进对锡克教文化的了解和理解，以及消除锡克教徒是“分离主义者和恐怖分子”的刻板印象。

;

;该网站由印度作家 Khushwant Singh 于 2017 年推出，是打击针对印度 3000 万锡克教徒社区不断上升的仇恨犯罪的努力的一部分。印度、英国和美国等国家。

;

;Khushwant Singh 曾撰写《Sikhs Unlimited》，记录了美国和英国锡克教徒的成就，他表示该网站是一个关于成功的“开源”平台当代锡克教徒在技术、艺术、医学、政治和金融等领域的影响力。

;

;9 月 11 日的袭击标志着反穆斯林情绪的上升，而锡克教徒经常与穆斯林混淆，因为他们的头巾和胡须，也被迫应对越来越多的仇恨犯罪。

;

;印度的锡克教徒被称为“哈利斯坦”分离主义者，他们希望从印度和巴基斯坦中分离出一个主权国家。在 20 世纪 80 年代和 90 年代，数千名锡克教徒在旁遮普邦的叛乱运动中被杀。

;

;锡克教徒被贴上“反民族主义者”的标签，并据称在因农业问题而爆发的抗议活动中侮辱了印度国旗。 2020 年和 2021 年的改革。

;

;今年 3 月，警方因涉嫌复兴哈利斯坦运动而对“精神领袖”阿姆里特帕尔·辛格 (Amritpal Singh) 进行搜捕，导致旁遮普邦大量锡克教男子被捕。

;

;在美国，联邦调查局 (FBI) 数据显示，2020 年至 2021 年间，反锡克教仇恨犯罪增加了 140%，从 89 起增加到 214 起。英国 2021-22 年报告的针对锡克教的仇恨犯罪增加了 169%去年，锡克教徒报告了 112 起案件。

;

;一名印度教徒在澳大利亚袭击锡克教徒，在印度受到英雄般的欢迎

;

;为了应对日益增长的敌意，全球锡克教徒之路取得了成功著名锡克教徒的故事，包括豪华酒店老板 Prithvi Raj Singh Oberoi、马拉松运动员 Fauja Singh、印度裔英国导演 Gurinder Chadha、印度前总理曼莫汉·辛格和苏格兰名厨托尼·辛格。

;

;Gurutej Singh Khalsa，他的由于自己与偏见的擦肩而过，他创办了安全公司 Akal Security, Inc，该公司也出现在该网站上。 1979 年，Khalsa 在新墨西哥州的执法工作工作了 18 个月后，因为戴着头巾和胡须（这是锡克教的象征）而被解雇。

;

;Khalsa 于 1980 年创办的 Akal Security，后来成为一家美国联邦政府国土安全的关键服务提供者。

;

;“这些事件使我成为一个更坚强的个人和更坚强的锡克教徒，并让我更深入地了解为什么我们保留头发和系头巾， ”现居新加坡的卡尔萨说道。

;

;锡克教慈善组织 Turbans 4 Australia 的悉尼阿马尔·辛格 (Amar Singh) 表示，他目睹了据称当地人和一部分“右派”对社区的仇恨。 “-wing”是澳大利亚印度政府的印度教支持者。

;

;他补充说，在全球宗教和政治动态发生变化之际，该网站将对社区形象产生“积极”影响。< /p>;

;Khushwant Singh 表示，尽管需要数年时间才能“治愈、安抚和纠正”社会犯下的集体错误，但人们可以通过更多的知识和理解来对抗仇恨和偏见。

;

;他说，网站上的个人资料都是根据他们激励社区的成就而精心挑选的，并补充说，从优秀者中选出优秀者是一项“艰巨”的工作。

;

;其他非营利组织也加大了努力以应对反锡克教仇恨犯罪的增加。总部位于美国的锡克教联盟致力于打击基于偏见的暴力，该组织利用其社交媒体页面来促进美国锡克教徒可以“有尊严地生活”的氛围，而总部位于加拿大的非营利组织世界锡克教组织则揭穿了有关锡克教徒的错误信息。通过社交媒体，促进社区权利。

;

;在印度教徒占多数的北方邦，锡克教徒、穆斯林和基督徒“生活在恐惧之中”

;

;全球锡克教小径也在非锡克教徒。

;

;昌迪加尔的药品供应商 Vishwas Ahuja 定期访问该网站，他表示这些故事有助于消除围绕锡克教徒的“神话”，锡克教徒在印度受到负面描绘。

;

;“人们认为锡克教徒只从事农业，但该网站显示他们是酒店经营者、运动员、IT 专家等等，”阿胡贾说。 “正在被排斥的社区应该采取这种记录成功故事的举措。”

;

;伊斯兰堡作家塔米娜·阿齐兹·阿尤布（Tahmina Aziz Ayub）（笔名普纳姆·阿齐兹·阿尤布）在 网站上读到了关于前印度领导人曼莫汉·辛格 (Manmohan Singh) 的文章。网站并主动提出将其翻译成乌尔都语，这是一种在巴基斯坦广泛使用的语言。

;

;阿尤布说，曼莫汉·辛格 (Manmohan Singh) 10 岁之前一直生活在印度不可分割的恰夸瓦尔 (Chakwal)（现在是巴基斯坦的一部分），乌尔都语版本的他的故事在她的国家会有“很多人接受”。

;

;该网站上的人物、居住在美国的古尔迪普·辛格·帕尔 (Gurdeep Singh Pall) 在从坎普尔出发的火车上遭遇暴民袭击锡克教徒后，差点离开印度。 1984 年，印度前总理英迪拉·甘地 (Indira Gandhi) 被两名锡克教保镖暗杀后，兰契 (Ranchi) 访问了兰契。

;

;现任微软商业人工智能公司副总裁的 Pall 表示，该网站可以激励年轻的锡克教徒将自己视为社区的“领导者”，并提高锡克教徒的全球认知，而不是局限于狭隘的观点。

;

;居住在伦敦的哈塞夫·辛格·贝恩斯 (Harsev Singh Bains)，印度工人协会副主席，印度工人协会是历史最悠久的工人协会英国的印度移民团体也表示，这些故事将鼓励锡克教徒将自己视为全球成就者，而不是“分离主义者和恐怖分子”。

;中国和俄罗斯正在寻求通过与受制裁国家接触来扩大上海合作组织分析人士表示，该组织最初关注的是安全，但当前的气候和俄罗斯入侵乌克兰的影响也推动了加强其安全的努力。伊莱达·尼哈尔 (Ilayda Nijhar) 表示，通过将伊朗纳入其中并让白俄罗斯走上入盟之路，它向世界“发出了一个信号”，表明欧亚大陆有更大程度的一体化和对抗西方自由秩序的选择，全球事务智库 ODI 的全球风险分析师。

;

;“我们看到上海合作组织在世界‘不结盟’地区越来越受欢迎……从地缘政治角度来看，中国和俄罗斯正在寻求发挥作用”

;

;中国和俄罗斯于 2001 年与哈萨克斯坦、吉尔吉斯斯坦、塔吉克斯坦和乌兹别克斯坦等中亚共和国建立了安全联盟。印度和巴基斯坦于2017年加入。伊朗今年加入，另一个受到西方制裁的国家白俄罗斯预计明年加入。

;

;成员国还可以邀请“对话伙伴”参加专门的会议讨论。到目前为止，已有十多个国家获得了这一地位，最新的国家是巴林、科威特、阿拉伯联合酋长国、马尔代夫和缅甸。

;

;Raffaello Pantucci，拉惹勒南学院高级研究员新加坡国际研究中心表示，俄罗斯上周呼吁加强欧盟之间的合作，“再次向世界表明，他们有其他选择，西方可以将其排除在其想要的任何结构之外”。

;< h3>;在中国主导的峰会上，印度拒绝支持北京的基础设施愿景;

;他补充道：“有趣的是，这些[国家]通常并不敌视西方，但仍然参与其中，印度是最明显的一个，实际上也越来越多地包括中亚国家。”

;

;北京清华大学一带一路战略研究院研究员祖恩·艾哈迈德·汗 (Zoon Ahmed Khan) 表示：“[成员国]所有国家共识是，上合组织国家乃至南半球国家都受到发达国家许多胁迫性政策的影响。因此，他们看到了共同努力的共同点。”

;

;汗补充道：“我认为，自俄罗斯-乌克兰危机开始以来，上合组织的许多国家都感到自己很容易受到全球经济的影响。经济挑战。能源安全和粮食安全是重大挑战。”

;

;成员国正在寻求深化欧盟的经济作用，乌兹别克斯坦呼吁制定“统一的交通互联互通地图”，而哈萨克斯坦则呼吁建立联合投资基金和更多的能源合作.

;

;成员们还支持中国国家主席习近平和普京关于在贸易中增加使用本国货币而不是美元的呼吁，并对数字一体化表示“强烈支持”。

; >;

;习近平还再次呼吁建立上海合作组织开发银行，这是北京的一项长期政策，但迄今为止进展甚微。

;

;潘图奇表示，中国希望上海合作组织专注于

;

;“他再次提出这一建议表明他们认为现在仍然是一个合适的时机，”他说。

;

;尤其是俄罗斯，其态度发生了重大转变。普京向邻国发表讲话，呼吁上合组织建立“必要的支付基础设施”，以加强区域经济一体化并建立“独立的金融结构”。

;

;普京对上合组织虚拟频道表示，俄罗斯“团结一致”瓦格纳叛变几天后举行的峰会

;

;潘图奇表示，俄罗斯早期“基本上拒绝”该组织，但由于担心中国在其“后院”的影响力而加入。

;

;但现在它越来越多上合组织将上合组织视为西方的堡垒，因为它通过地区反恐结构等机制加强安全合作。

;

;ODI 的 Nijhar 表示，习近平和普京正在推动减少对美元的依赖符合他们“将本国货币定位为美元的可靠和可持续替代品的雄心”。

;

; Sun, 09 Jul 2023 12:50:05 +0800 Singapore home rents catch up with Hong Kong’s as fortunes of rival business hubs divergehttps://www.scmp.com/business/article/3226892/singapore-home-rents-catch-hong-kongs-fortunes-rival-business-hubs-diverge?utm_source=rss_feed

;香港和新加坡的住宅租金在差距大幅缩小后仍接近平价the past five years, signifying the diverging fortunes of the rival Asian financial hubs, official data compiled by property consultancy CBRE showed.

;

;In 2018, before Hong Kong was hit by an unprecedented wave of social unrest, the rental gulf between the two cities was as high as 82 per cent, with Hong Kong widely labelled as the world's most unaffordable housing market.

;

;That chasm has shrivelled to about 12.8 per cent in May, with average Singapore rents at US$3.80 per sq ft while in Hong Kong rents averaged US$4.28 per sq ft.

;

;At one point – in the first quarter of the year – the gap had narrowed to as little as 6 per cent with rents in Singapore at about US$3.78 per square feet, nearly catching up with Hong Kong's US$4 per sq ft.

;

;“Rents are a function of demand and supply,” said Henry Chin, global head of investor thought leadership and head of research, Asia-Pacific for CBRE. “Both cities are in completely different stages of the real estate cycle. Singapore is on the rise and perhaps close to the peak while Hong Kong is at the bottom of the current cycle. With the reopening of the border with the rest of the world, we expect rents in Hong Kong to recover.”

;

;There are a myriad of reasons why rents in Singapore and Hong Kong are near parity, industry experts say. In 2019, when Hong Kong saw violent anti-government protests, an estimated US$4 billion of capital moved to Singapore from the city, according to a Bloomberg report.

;

;Hong Kong ends reign as most expensive city for expats, Singapore gains 8 places

;

;The outflows continued over the next three years with Hong Kong enforcing some of the strictest Covid-19 restrictions in the world, a factor which also hastened waves of emigration with both locals and expatriates relocating either temporarily or permanently.

;

;Last year, Hong Kong's population dropped 0.9 per cent to 7.33 million from 2021, according to government data released in February. It was the third straight year of population decline and the resultant diminished pool of tenants and homebuyers had an impact on the property market.

;

;Meanwhile, Singapore's stability and widely-praised management of the coronavirus pandemic further burnished its reputation as a premier business hub.

;

;Many businesses and professionals found Hong Kong's pandemic curbs too restrictive and relocated to Singapore, which then saw higher rental demand.

;

;Singapore's prudent timing in reopening its economy in late 2022 was a “catalyst” for international workers' return to the city, and demand for rental properties was further stoked by successive hikes in stamp duty rates which made property purchases more expensive, according to Knight Frank.

;

;For the rest of the year, home rents in both Hong Kong and Singapore are likely to face upwards pressure, although Singapore rental increases could be moderated by higher property supply in a slowing economy, according Ismail Gafoor, CEO of Singapore-listed PropNex Realty. He expects about 18,000 new units to enter the property market, nearly double the number in 2022.

;

;Still, full-year rents are forecast to rise by 5 per cent, said Tricia Song, head of research for Singapore and Southeast Asia at CBRE.

;

;“For private homes, rents were essentially flat for the 10 years before 2022 due to oversupply and mediocre population growth,” Song said. “With future supply likely to be below historical average, higher property taxes and higher replacement costs, rents are unlikely to fall back to pre-Covid levels.”

;

;Other analysts expect higher rental increments in Singapore.

;

;“We are projecting rentals to grow at a pace of 10 to 12 per cent for the whole of 2023, relatively slower in comparison to 2022 where overall residential rentals grew by nearly 30 per cent for the whole year,” said PropNex's Gafoor.

;

;Meanwhile, Hong Kong is expected to see sustained demand for rental properties as rising interest rates and heftier down-payment requirements make outright purchases expensive.

;

;“The relatively large lump sum of down-payments is encouraging more young expats to opt for rental housing options,” said Rosanna Tang, executive director and head of research in Hong Kong at Cushman and Wakefield. “Given the rate hike environment coupled with uncertain global economic outlook, potential homebuyers may choose to stay on the sidelines and temporarily seek rental properties instead.”

;

;Rents are forecast to rise by 5 per cent to 8 per cent this year, boosted by demand for housing from foreign talent and non-local students relocating to the city, Tang said.

; Sun, 09 Jul 2023 12:50:05 +0800 Hong Kong, mainland China to create plan within months for Greater Bay Area data transfer deal covering banking, personal care details, technology chief revealshttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/society/article/3227062/hong-kong-mainland-china-create-plan-within-months-greater-bay-area-data-transfer-deal-covering?utm_source=rss_feed

;Hong Kong and mainland Chinese authorities will develop an action plan within months for a deal to make cross-border data transfers involving banking and personal care information easier in the Greater Bay Area, the city's technology chief has revealed.

;

;Secretary for Innovation, Technology and Industry Sun Dong on Sunday also said Hongkongers should not worry about privacy invasion as personal data was protected under strict laws.

;

;Sun stressed that the memorandum signed between the local government and the Cyberspace Administration of China (CAC) in June mainly targeted data flowing from mainland cities in the bay area to Hong Kong, and aimed to help the city become an international information hub.

;

;The bay area refers to Beijing's scheme to integrate Hong Kong, Macau and nine mainland Chinese cities into an economic powerhouse.

;

;“Previously, it was very difficult to transfer data from industries such as banking and healthcare to Hong Kong. Now, after years of negotiation with the country, we have signed the memorandum to help data flow within the bay area,” Sun said.

;

;The technology chief described the deal as a “big gift from the country to celebrate the 26th anniversary of Hong Kong's return to Chinese rule”. He revealed that a detailed action plan would be developed within a few months.

;

;He added authorities were working with the CAC to draft a standard contract for the free flow of data within the bay area.

;

;Hong Kong aims to develop its own ChatGPT-like platform, technology chief says

;

;“The country has a very high threshold for data leaving its soil. But for Hong Kong, the threshold will be significantly lower,” Sun said.

;

;The CAC launched a “standard contract” covering the data of mainland residents on June 1. Under the contract, data leaving the mainland must meet several conditions which include being deemed “non-critical information infrastructure operators” and involve no more than 1 million people.

;

;Sun stressed residents' privacy would be protected. “Hong Kong's current laws concerning individual privacy will stay put. And we have strict regulations on exporting data out of Hong Kong. So residents need not worry about data intrusion,” he said.

;

;Hong Kong and mainland agree to cross-border data deal after new rules in China

;

;Sun was referring to the Personal Data (Privacy) Ordinance, which came into effect in 1996, and the Guidance on Personal Data Protection in Cross-border Data Transfer, which was issued by the local privacy watchdog in 2014. Both prohibit the transfer of personal information to places outside the city, except in certain circumstances.

;

;Chief Executive John Lee Ka-chiu earlier said a cross-border data flow pilot programme in the bay area would be launched later this year during the 2023 Pan-Pearl River Delta Regional Co-operation Chief Executives Joint Conference in Guiyang, Guizhou province.

;

;Technology chief Sun on Sunday said “data was gold” in the future, as he shared details about his recent trip to Guizhou, one of the mainland's poorest provinces which began cultivating a big data industry in 2014. The province has become home to many world-renowned tech giants such as Apple.

;

;Sun added that the 16 state key laboratories in the city would be restructured to better answer the nation's needs regarding chips, artificial intelligence and aerospace technology within the year.

;

;He also said Hong Kong's international image had been affected by sanctions imposed by the US and European countries.

;

;“Misunderstandings still exist. But the impact is not disruptive. Hong Kong should be confident that it is capable of carving out a unique development trail with the back of the country,” he said.

;At a shopping centre in Bangkok's old town, every few days an unlikely clientele of young Chinese tourists voraciously pick through the rows of pale blue or white Thai school uniforms for sale.

;

;The link between Chinese visitors and an obscure Southeast Asian school uniform – disliked by many Thai pupils who have to wear boy scout shorts or knee-length skirts – is a 2010 romcom, A Little Thing Called Love, which was picked up by Chinese streaming giant Bilibili.

;

;Also helping the viral craze is Chinese singer Ju Jingyi, who posed in the US$8-US$10 uniform made famous in the film earlier this year and posted the photos to her Weibo page.

;

;Since then the “Sri Pan School Uniform Shop” and its peers have welcomed a handful of Chinese tourists who make the pilgrimage across Bangkok to buy the clothes, have their names embroidered in Thai on the shirt pocket, and then pose for a photo – which is now part of many Chinese influencer's Thai bucket-list.

;

;In one Facebook post entitled “China boys and China girls”, six young Chinese visitors pose in school uniform, the boys with the knots of their ties low and the three women in complete uniform, including the 300 baht (US$8.50) school shoes and white socks combo common to many public schools.

;

;Thai media has picked up on the trend as a reflection of Thailand's growing 'T-Wave' of music, idols, film and TV series – some new, many recycled – churned out by the country's relentless content creators and shared across Asia through a flurry of new platforms.

;

;Many of the new fans are frequent travellers to a kingdom that is cheaper and more accessible than South Korea, which remains the region's dominant pop-culture leader.

;

;Thailand's tourist authorities are desperate to cash in on the “soft power” allure of global stars like Lalisa Manobal – Lisa from Blackpink – as well as a growing list of local talents making their way onto a larger stage, such as 20-year-old rapper Milli.

;

;Thai actress questioned for buying cyanide linked to serial killer

;

;Thailand has attracted 12.5 million tourists so far this year as it looks to appeal to young, high-spending Asians, with Western visitors – not including Russians – falling behind Malaysians, Chinese and Singaporeans.

;

;Brand Thailand is shining as Chinese mega-platforms such as Viu, IQiyi and Bilibili hoover up content such as 2022 series Cutie Pie and KinnPorsche.

;

;New fans can attend concerts or meet their idols for far less than their Korean equivalents, as K-pop becomes increasingly unaffordable and oversubscribed.

;

;

;

;Thailand's appeal extends well beyond China.

;

;Thai “boy's love” (BL) dramas, a genre in which the kingdom now leads with its handsome stars, romantic plot lines and hazy sexuality, are gaining popularity in China, Singapore and Malaysia.

;

;Singaporean Rae Chua, 23, became interested in Thai pop culture when she first saw 2020 BL smash hit 2gether on Netflix. In the code of Asian pop culture, the genre is otherwise known as Y Series, derived from the Japanese term yaoi, which refers to fictional male characters involved in homoerotic relationships.

;

;Chua says her favourite Thai idols are Jumpol Adulkittiporn and Atthaphan Phunsawat – nicknamed Off and Gun, respectively.

;

;Over time, her love for Thai pop culture has expanded to include learning the language and Thai music, which she finds less “repetitive” than K-pop.

;

;“I want to go to Thai music festivals because whenever I see them, it really feels like the singers are genuinely having fun singing their music,” Chua said. “As for dramas, I cannot deny it's because of how good-looking the actors are, but they're also really talented and the scriptwriters are really creative with their plots.”

;

;She says that the pool of overseas fans like herself has been growing, noting a move away from K-pop and K-culture.

;

;“Getting tickets is always a struggle,” she said. “Whenever I go to fan meets, the common trait among fans is that most of them are shifting from K-pop to the Thai entertainment space.”

;

;Thai singer-songwriter Jeff Satur's two-night show in February in Singapore was sold out. Event organisers added the second date due to overwhelming demand.

;

;“Thai pop culture has been very effective in using the internet to be seen,” Singaporean Nicholas Lim, 25, an architectural designer, told This Week in Asia.

;

;“They are capitalising on the ubiquity of the internet in Southeast Asia,” he said.

;

;

;

;Anuphan Phanthong, founder of Random Dance Bangkok, a fortnightly dance-off in the Thai capital that pulls in hundreds of young T-, K- and J-pop devotees, says T-Wave still has a long way to go to upstage its Korean forebear.

;

;“T-Pop has become a lot more popular this year with new platforms and channels picking up the music,” the Korean-speaking emcee said. “But our choreography and music composition is weak compared to K-pop. We're probably around 50 per cent below the K-pop standard right now.”

;

;Random Dance Bangkok events have offered young people a chance to showcase moves honed over TikTok during the pandemic to the public stage. Some take their choreography very seriously, hoping to get spotted by the Thai, Korean and Japanese agents who sometimes patrol the plaza outside, while others are in cosplay or just enjoying an evening out under the blaring speakers.

;

;Still, the standard has been set by K-pop: the once state-backed juggernaut; maker and breaker of dreams; and provider of the mega-bands, peerless choreography and jaw-dropping concerts that have taken the world by storm.

;

;Until Thailand backs its talent pool with money and a matching level of ruthless commercialism, the handbrake will always be on the industry, Anuphan says.

;

;“K-pop dominates Asia, so to get there we have to match them. If agencies in Thailand start to train kids with the same level of intensity of K-pop, then maybe T-pop has that chance to hit the global market.”

;

;

;

;For some, the tide has already turned – and it started during the pandemic.

;

;Former K-pop fan, Singaporean Puteri Amira Binte Mansor, 25, started watching Thai remakes of popular Korean dramas – like Full House and Boys Over Flowers – before getting drawn into Thai pop culture.

;

;“During Covid, I came across new dramas that I found appealing. Recently, I found a new friend in Thailand who introduced me to Thai songs,” she said.

;

;How K-dramas, K-pop and Korean movies took over the world

;

;Since her conversion, Puteri Amira has flown to Thailand twice to catch her favourite stars, spending about S$900 (US$665) for a four-day trip in May to catch a Beluca concert, featuring Thai BL actors Jumpol, Atthaphan, Thitipoom Techaapaikhun and Tawan Wihakarat.

;

;While she concedes the pool of T-pop fans is still “small”, Puteri Amira has seen the numbers climbing steadily in the last two years, adding that the showmanship of Thai stars is a step up from their Korean counterparts.

;

;“For Beluca's performance, there was a concert segment where they sang, then they had a musical, fashion show and invited guests,” she said. “That's the difference between K-pop; the actors are more well-rounded.”

;An online influencer in China has revealed that a man arrested for burglary had been squatting in her vacant island villa for a fortnight, during which time he helped himself to the contents of her liquor cabinet.

;

;Police in the city of Sanya, on the southern island of Hainan, announced the arrest in a statement early last week, the Jiupai News reported.

;

;The next day, a blogger on the social media platform Douyin, who calls herself Piyou, said the residence that was broken into was hers.

;

;“Dear friends, do you know how a person feels when they find out a news event is about them?” she wrote on Douyin.

;

;“A stranger climbed over a wall and broke into my home. He lived there for about half a month,” she said in an online video.

;

;It was not clear from the video how Piyou discovered that her villa had been broken into.

;

;The blogger, who has nearly 30 million followers on Douyin continued: “What I admire about him is that according to what he confessed to the police, he rode a stolen bicycle 300km (186 miles) from Haikou to Sanya before sneaking into my house.”

;

;The 30-year-old intruder, surnamed Zhu, told the police that when he arrived in Sanya on June 8, he discovered the villa was unoccupied.

;

;He then climbed over a security wall, broke into the premises and proceeded to take a rest, presumably tired from his long journey.

;

;Zhu then decided to stay a while and drank six bottles of the Chinese liquor Maotai, which Piyou had stored there.

;

;However, his free stay came to an abrupt halt on June 24, when a housekeeper arrived and called the police.

;

;Back on her video blog, Piyou wrote that she had decided to refer to the squatter as “Maotai Savage Brother”, an apparent reference to Zhu's long hair and shaggy appearance.

;

;“This saga is so unbelievable!” Piyou said, adding: “I'd like to remind the public that if you have bought a house and you don't usually live there, you'd better install surveillance cameras. Otherwise a Maotai Savage Brother could break into your house and drink the alcohol stored in your home.”

;

;Cai Yaqi, a Chongqing-based lawyer, said on Douyin that the length of time Zhu will spend in jail depends on the value of the six bottles of Maotai he drank.

;

;“If the combined value is below 30,000 yuan (US$4,100), he will be sentenced to less than three years in jail. If the value is between 30,000 and 300,000 yuan, the sentence will range from three to 10 years,” Cai said.

;

;Zhu will also be ordered to pay compensation for the alcohol he drank, and the villa's property management company will be held liable for dereliction of duties, according to Cai.

;

;Piyou's video discussing the burglary has received 2.5 million likes and 400,000 comments online.

;

;“It's so dramatic! It could be turned into a movie,” wrote one person.

;

;“Maybe he is one of Piyou's fans,” joked another.

;

;A third online observer also had some advice: “The property management people did a poor job. By the way, check if the intruder hid any surveillance devices in your home.”
